Fields.DialogueText: Huh! Ahrgh! Kah! Ofph-Autsch!
Ow! What was that for, Roeder?!
Oh! Kapitän! Excellent timing! To keep in top shape against the other Schiffsdamen, I have to maintain my physical form.
But...they aren't watching you fight every single second, Roeder.
Nein. They watch every second of my breath, footsteps, and even how I enjoy my Wein.

Fields.MenuText: Belles have other duties than to watch you, Roeder.
Aren't you taking this a little too dramatically?
Maintaining toughness, I see?

Fields.DialogueText: Kapitän, you know nothing, with all due respect. They gossip constantly of how I am lollygagging among the crew!
Nein! I'm simply being true to my sense of conscientiousness!
Hah! Good, Kapitän. I should not be surprised the Kapitän of our fleet takes great pride in learning the rules of our blood!
Anyway, you must spar against me.
Wha-what!? I'm not hitting you, Roeder.
Hah. You do not have to. Hragh!
Augh!
In combat, you get no break against your enemy. Have the Prussian virtues not taught you anything?!
... Let's go with "discipline." I'm not going to be provoked into a fight when I have obligations elsewhere.
Ah. Kapitän... I have taught you well. My star pupil!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Tsk. Nixe. Has your leader not taught you anything about sense of- Autsch!
... Roeder, are you all right?
I am fine, Kapitän. Focus on the horizons, instead!
@BATTLE
What happened out there? For a brief second you looked like you were in tremendous pain.
Ich weiss es nicht.
You don't know?
Me? See an Arzt!? I have been a healthy Schiffsdame since I have existed!

Fields.MenuText: If you are sick, you have to know when to go!
As your Kapitän, I order you to visit the on-call doctor. Subordination!
They won't hurt you, Roeder...

Fields.DialogueText: Nein! What will the rest of the crew think when they see Diether von Roeder go to a doctor!? Erbärmlich!
... Why do you keep getting me with Prussian virtues?
Hurt me? Damage my reputation is what they will do to me!
Please, Roeder. Do it for me? As your friend?
... You must never speak a word of it to the crew. Do I make myself clear, Kapitän?
You have my word, Roeder.
... Understood.
*ALARM*
I'm not detecting any mechanical defects. The engineers seem unconcerned.
Okay, but that's your ship form. Your human avatar? Could something be wrong with your body?
Might be worth checking in with the doctor. There's a lot we don't know about... well, you.
Back off, filthy Nixe. The only ship in this fleet to fear is me and my Prussian virtues!
@BATTLE
Roeder, how did the visit to the–
Silence!
Huh?
You were to never speak a word to anyone! How dare you bring this up again!?
Roeder, there's no one here. It is just you and me on deck at the mome–
Shout so the whole fleet and even the Nixe can hear!

Fields.MenuText: What has gotten into you?!
Take it easy now, Roeder.
Talk to me...What happened?

Fields.DialogueText: You... You! All of this is your doing, Kapitän.
How do you expect me to take it easy when I cannot control what is happening?!
Off with your limbs, filth.
Roeder, listen to me. This is not like you. Your words are harsh, but they have a warmth to them. Why is it like ice right now?
Tsk. Humans.... do not understand a thing.
Huh? Roeder, wait!...
Men! Maintain your sense of duty now! The battle at sea now is not the time to think, but to stop thinking. Straightforward should be your actions! Charge, men!
Jawohl, Schiffsdame!
What are you doing, sailor? Prepare the depth charges; do not loiter near me. Has your brain not heard the sounds of war around you!?
Uh, Schiffsdame...I have prepared–
Then be there for your crew! Just because you have finished a task, does not give you an excuse to be idle!
Ja-jawohl, Schiffsdame!
Roeder, are you feeling any better?
I do not know what you are referring to. Right now the focus is on the destruction of the Nixe!
Heh, I'll take that as a yes.
You, sailor! Man the- Autsch...
Roeder?
Schiffsdame?!
Elende! I am fine! Do not look at me like that! Back to your stations. Now!
Jawohl, Schiffsdame!

Fields.MenuText: Really, what did the doctor say, Roeder?
You need rest. Get to a bunk right now, Roeder.
Here... sit down for a little bit.

Fields.DialogueText: I told you, I am not discussing it with you, Kapitän.
I do not need such paltry necessities as you humans do, Kapitän.
Do not treat me like a human!
Roeder, don't disappear just- Augh... so we're back to this now, huh?
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Roeder, time to reappear...
Ah...The crew has done an outstanding job acquiring this Merlot.
You'll have to thank Thorsten for that.
Thorsten?
The rations for the alcohol were running dry for the crew and at port, there was no alcohol to be found. Thorsten was crafty enough to persuade a local bartender to sell his share to us.
Ah. Our supply officer has some sense of industriousness. Good to know.
Do remind me to thank him later. I love when my Merlot has more taste of plum than of black cherry. Such a soft wine...

Fields.MenuText: What cheese do you want to pair it with this time?
Shall I turn on the phonograph to help your experience?
May I try some, Roeder?

Fields.DialogueText: No question about it, Kapitän. Goat cheese, you may find it under the compartment right there. Ah, danke. Help yourself to the wine.
That is not necessary, Kapitän. Merlot shall be enjoyed in pleasure of good cheese and company. Music is not required of our situation at this present time. Please, take a glass for yourself instead.
Certainly, get the wine glass to your right. To the rim for you!
The reason for the drinking of this wine is to inform you of our next mission.
... So there was an underlying reason...
Ja, ja, but do not think ill of it! It is for the greater good of our fight!
So you want to get them out of their bind? Simple enough.
I have not finished, Kapitän. Nixe swarm the perimeter of our squadron.
... Wonderful. What is your planned action against this?
Heh, full frontal assault.
That's–
Glad you agree. After all, Merlot is an agreeable wine. To the deck!
... Okay. But only because I would've given the same orders myself.
@BATTLE
You see... in these coordinates, I have received distress signals from our fellow Schiffsdamen.
*ALARM*
Attention! There are Morganas in sight! Officers, to your stations, we must get rid of those things!
@BATTLE
Phew, after that battle, I'm starving...Huh? Where's the chef? The chef is sick today?
Yes, Kapitän! He's with the on-call doctor as we speak. Sorry for the inconvenience.
Bother...All right, I'll help myself to the kitchen. I won't take too much.
Uh, about that...
Hm, wonder what I should m–
Roeder!?
Uff....Too full....
What are you doing on the floor?
I have heard rumors, Kapitän. That when distressed, people tend to gorge themselves on their favorite food. At this present moment, I have eaten... 10 kg worth of Knieperkohl.
How on earth are you even still talking to me? That sounds like it can kill you!
Do not underestimate a Schiffsdame's appetite, Kapitän. If given the opportunity, we eat like a Scheunendrescher.
I'm not sure I get it.
The point is, Kapitän, I have done the necessary steps of stress relief.

Fields.MenuText: Do you feel better then?
Who did you hear these rumors from exactly?
I'm glad you're so proactive.

Fields.DialogueText: ... I do not know. Maybe Thorsten has better answers on this than I do.
I heard from Thorsten, Kapitän.
Yes, Thorsten highly recommended it for stress relief, Kapitän.
Somehow, I don't think Thorsten is helpful to your problems... Anyway, what are you stress relieving yourself from?
Have you ever tried being a Schiffsdame?
No, I have not.
Then do not come to me with your silly questions.
Really, what has gotten into you?
Crew, get ready for combat! We are under fire!
@BATTLE
Herr Kapitän?
Oh, hi, Roeder. The battle we just fought...
Nein, Kapitän. Say no more. The battle has made you weary, has it not?
War in general can make any person tired to be fair.
That is not what I mean. Did you feel responsible for the mistakes you have made last battle?

Fields.MenuText: Yeah, I do.
Not really.
Wait, I made mistakes last battle?

Fields.DialogueText: Now is the time to show your humility, Kapitän.
Think hard, you have made a few mistakes. Let your humility flow, Kapitän.
You always do, Kapitän.
No one ever knows the outcome of a battle. What mistakes you make, what may happen are out of your control. Bravery.
Bravery to keep going when all the mistakes have been executed. That is the makings of a true Kapitän.
Huh...Thanks, Roeder. I haven't thought of it like that before.
Nicht der Rede wert.
When did you become doting over my feel-ow!
Forget you ever heard of my sincerity.
Everyone! To your stations! Frederick, go to the–
Prussian virtue number 15! Herr Kapitän!
H-huh?
Even in the turmoil of battle, we must show discipline by remembering the virtues. Make the Nixe fear the Schiffsdamen!
Roeder, this–
If you utter another word how this is not the time to listen to the virtues, I will personally hurl you into the North Sea.
Nope, just wondering what the rest of the virtues were!
Sehr gut. Sincerity, discipline, loyalty, bravery, sense of duty, sense of order...! Give me another.

Fields.MenuText: Obedience!
Diligence!
Austerity!

Fields.DialogueText: Obedience... How far have you been obedient to me?
Diligence! An important Prussian virtue! One is almost astonished by far you have come without diligence.
Sehr gut. Consider it when you return to your palatial quarters, Kapitän!
Hah....
Very good. I expect the full recitation of the rest of the virtues at the next meal. Do I make myself clear?
Yes, Roeder!
... So I maintain that aspect at least.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Good work last night, men. Enjoy yourselves in the galley. Roeder, why don't you–
Of all the wonders of die Welt... How Manni Haff have I seen?
Roeder?
How Manni Haff set their Eis on die Butti of Sanssouci Castle or Brandenburg Gate? Pictures I have only seen... short of witnessing them in die jelecht.
Wine is being served again, I take it?
Wutt any of my awakened schwisters see any of those wonderful sights? What about me? Was'smitmir? Wai did ich leaf alles zuhind?

Fields.MenuText: ...Hello? Roeder? Food and wine are being served?...
Are you with me, Roeder?
Spacing off won't stop people from taking your share of the Merlot, Roeder.

Fields.DialogueText: If they had a taste, ich wonder what they would think of my Palette?
Why did it heff to be so?
What difference does it make? This Welt is still voll with lives.
Uh...Roeder? Where are you going? Roeder?...Roeder!...
Moment. Dett would be messy and ick-ick-ick.....nich schöhn.
*ALARM*
I'm not sure which I'm more worried about leaving alone. The Morganas or a drunk Roeder...
@BATTLE
Nixe! More and more nixen arrive like connoisseurs to a Pinot Grigio. Autsch, autsch, autsch... Augh....
Roeder? What's wrong?
... Did anyone see me stumble?
No, thankfully, the crew is actually late to hearing the sirens for once.
My head... twitches and burns. Someone is peeling it apart and I can't to stop the agony.
Roeder, be honest to me. What did the doctor diagnose you with?
...You would not understand, Kapitän.

Fields.MenuText: Roeder, I have heard about your past. If you let me in about that, I can hear you about your problems too.
Who is to say I wouldn't?
Roeder, I can't predict whether I will understand or not.

Fields.DialogueText: Nein, this is different. My past did not infect my mind.
I do, now drop the subject.
Fine, I have a magic mug that says you will not understand. Now get out of my sight!
Roeder! Don't you dare disappear on m-
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
... I'm right here. I got ya.
Okay. She did.
We're under attack! Has anyone seen the Belle? Tell her to get to her station!
@BATTLE
She ran past me after the battle, Kapitän.
Thanks, Thorsten. Oh - and please don't dispense advice to Roeder again. Ever.
... Sure.
Roeder? Are you in here? Ugh... why won't the cargo bay door open?
Leave! Verschwinden Sie! The likes of you should not approach me now!
Why? Is there someone else in there?
The Nixe. I refuse to let them out of here.
Roeder... you know full well that Morganas are generally not found in our cargo bays. And I think if one *had* materialized in there, she'd be yammering at us by now.
You do not understand, Dummkopf! There are evil entities that will destroy you if given the chance! I will not have it!

Fields.MenuText: Can I see these entities?
Are you positive they are with you in the cargo bay right now?
Roeder, if there's some kind of Morgana artifact in there, we need to get it properly secured for analysis or disposal.

Fields.DialogueText: Nein. Not even I can see them, Kapitän.
Ja. They breathe upon my neck and I have the sensation I am never alone...
It's not that easy!
Roeder... whatever entity is plaguing you in the cargo bay, we'll tackle it together. You know that.
This... is something you don't have the power to tackle, Kapitän. I am sorry - but, please, leave this place for now. I must think...
Roeder...
Kapitän. Hngh! That was a good warm up...
Roeder! You came out of the cargo bay at long last! Good to see you again.
Ja, I have to reshape myself once more. All the time spent in the cargo bay made me weak. Without toughness, I am nothing but a soft cabbage.
You're not weak to me, Roeder. You are strong, with or without training. What matters is your resolve.
Kapitän, with all due respect, physical form is equally as important as mental. So, let us resume our sparring!
What!? We're still going back to that?
Natürlich! You backed out with an argument for discipline before - but courage and bravery? You lacked both of these important virtues!

Fields.MenuText: Can't I use self-denial to get myself out of this, Roeder? I don't have to fight you.
What if I argued that a sense of order precluded Captain and Belle beating on each other where the crew might see?
I can counter this argument with probity! I *honestly* don't feel like doing this.

Fields.DialogueText: I have explained before, courage and bravery knock your argument to the ground.
Heh, I don't see that virtue coming to save you now.
Nein. Truthfulness will not save you against a good, old-fashioned duel.
All right, I'll try this again. I won't-UFF!
Hah! Good fashioned punch to the solar plexus leaves the opponent struggling for the crisp air of Prussia!
Ugh...
... You definitely cannot handle the air of Prussia, can you?
No... I'd say I can't, Roeder... pain...
... You will be fine!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Kapitän? Wake up!
Agreement or nicht, no English Schiffsdame can match my firepower!
@BATTLE
So, why were you talking about an English Belle all of a sudden, Roeder?
Hmph, have you heard of the English Schiffsdamen? Those sad excuses claim they are fast.
And now I hear they propose to race me, Destroyer of this fleet?! Verteidigerin of noble ideals!?
And... that's inappropriate?
Natürlich, I cannot race them. No matter how much I would like to put them in their place, the Züricher Vereinbarung, I am sure, would not condone such contests.
Putting down vengeance that easily, huh?
Kapitän, if you are trying to get me to do this, you are crazy... but supportive of my feelings. Danke.
But behold! A graceful Schiffsdame does not need to flaunt her speed, but- EEEK! (slips) Au-au-autsch!...
Uh... are you all right?
Ja, ja, schon gut!

Fields.MenuText: Don't worry, I was the only one who saw that.
Heh, I'll forget I saw the great Diether von Roeder slip upon the ship's waxing.
I swear, I won't say a word!

Fields.DialogueText: Sehr gut. Ahem...
Sei bloß ruhig! You will say nothing of this incident!
For your sake, I am glad then.
Now... where did I leave off?
... About how you shouldn't race English Belles because you don't flaunt your abilities?
Who said those silly things? When we meet, we will race... and then we will see who is the fastest of the Schiffsdamen!
Well, I tried...
*ALARM*
Hah... hah....
Roeder? Whoa...
It burns... too much right now, Kapitän.
Easy now, just lay your arm around my neck. Hoppla!
Anyway, let's get you away from crew traffic. Hah... I forget how you carry your weaponry wherever you go, Roeder.
A necessity.
Right. So what happened this time, Roeder?
... I do not know this time, Kapitän. I was unable to maintain my balance any longer. My vision blurred and I felt the world would not last within my eyes.
And you still won't tell me what the doctor diagnosed you with?
Nein.

Fields.MenuText: After all we've been through together, why not!?
I worry about you a lot though, Roeder.
Roeder, this is affecting your performance. We can't just pretend it isn't.

Fields.DialogueText: Because you are a human, and that is forever what you will be!
That makes no difference. It does not make this illness disappear from within.
You question my reliability? Enough! I can move on my own!
It's not getting any better with maintaining her here for more than a few minutes at a time. I have to change something...
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Hah... what a day to live in.
Hey, Roeder. Reviewing the virtues?
... Something like that. I am seeing what I lack at this present moment of time.

Fields.MenuText: Self-denial?
Bravery?
Discipline?

Fields.DialogueText: Ah, you may not be too far off.
How are you implying I am not the bravest out of all the Schiffsdamen?!
No, but I already know who lacks it...
But in seriousness, I have failed these virtues. I have failed incorruptibility.
Wait, really? How did you manage that? You are one of the strictest Belles I have known.
Heh... I have failed to maintain the pride that I, Diether von Roeder, have maintained all these months. Who am I to deserve such a name when this Schiffsdame acts out violently?
That's just who you are. No matter what you are sick with and how it makes you act, you deserve to have the name you have now.
We are all proud of you, Roeder, and I am not just saying that.
Danke... I need more time before the Nixe arrives. Please keep watch while I review the virtues a second time.
No problem, Roeder.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Roeder?
You know where to find her, Kapitän.
Ah, same place, huh? Got it.
... I refuse such a drink...
But you love a good Merlot, right? Good with goat cheese and good company. Remember?
I said I refuse the drink!
Roeder, there has to be something I can do to help you - but it would really help if you opened up. I don't know what you're ill with... and I can't even see you smile.
I never smile.
Sometimes when you eat cheese you do.
Nein. Not the point. Please leave this place at once, Kapitän.

Fields.MenuText: What if I don't?
I'm not leaving this place.
If I leave, will you be all right?

Fields.DialogueText: Then expect me to give you a lecture so literate, that the scholars from all over the world would be congratulating me on my findings.
Leave or I will make you with my courage, Dummkopf.
Who is to say I know? All I know is I require peace.
Once again I guess I have no choice but to leave. I'll just conveniently forget the Merlot by the cargo bay door...
If that pleases you.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Roeder? You're in there, aren't you? I've brought a good Merlot. Think you'll like this one. Thorsten picked it out especially for you!
Kapitän, I have found you.
Roeder! Great to–
Do not act so joyfully. Restraint.
Ahah, apologies. What may I do for you?
I have been thinking about godliness and tolerance.
Oh? What is that?
Tolerance. But I have realized I did not show it to you for you already have knowledge of this virtue.
I'm not sure I understand.
You are in command of Schiffsdamen from various countries - some I despise more than others.
I myself may have failed to display the proper tolerance, but the fleet that you've built is a different matter.

Fields.MenuText: I hadn't thought of it that way.
Actually, I think you have displayed that virtue yourself, Roeder.
What are the other countries you despise?

Fields.DialogueText: Of course you have not. You lack discipline to see it.
I do not believe I have, but thank you for attempting to flatter me. It did not work.
The English, the French. When the current threat is over and the Neutrality Fleet is dissolved, I will strike...
Ah, die Nixen sind da!
Thank you for not disappearing for once.
...Do not push your luck.
@BATTLE
Roeder? Oh you're enjoying a Pinot and music. Lovely.
A German Requiem by Johannes Brahms. I have said that Merlot does not need music to be enjoyed, but this Pinot Grigio does.
Can't say this is music that would make you happy though, Roeder.
Hmph. Sincerity, Kapitän. This may make me happy, you do not know.
Well, I do know you enough that sad things actually make you sad. You are not that much of a mystery as you let on to be, Roeder.
I can tell this music and Pinot Grigio drinking has nothing to do with your illness. So talk.
Hah...Sometimes I regret letting you into my mind. The sailor...do you remember the sailor that tore down the virtues and died in battle?
Engelke.
Karl. For some reason, I remember all of him. The feelings all came flooding back to me like a wave that was pulled to shore ever so tightly.
I wonder sometimes... was I to be blamed for his death? Perhaps a Nixe would not have hurt him if I cared more about our defense at the time.

Fields.MenuText: You are not to be blamed, Roeder.
I feel like I should be blamed for his death.
No one is to be blamed for his death.

Fields.DialogueText: Danke... I am not looking for condolences, though.
No, Kapitän.
Exactly, Kapitän.
No one is to be blamed for his death. The Nixe, ruthless as she is, may not know what she's doing subconsciously.
If any of us knew he would die that day, we would have assessed the situation, but made sure he would still be alive today.
What are you trying to get at, Roeder?
I feel like... his death was in vain if there was no one to blame. He died... meaninglessly. Like we all will someday.
Roeder... he did not, and you know that all too well.
Maybe I do not know that, Kapitän. I lack courage to know.
Roeder....
Nixe...
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Auuuughgh!
@BATTLE
Kapitän, can I ask you something?
Of course.
Have you ever lost control of your mind? Has it ever revolted against you?

Fields.MenuText: Revolted? What do you mean?
...It has a few times.
I haven't had that happen before.

Fields.DialogueText: Hm, how would I describe this concept?
Are you sure it revolted or are you saying you were indecisive over an event?
That is fine. I do not wish for anyone to have a loss of control of their conscious.
When the mind revolts or loses control, it tends to think different things from the programmed path. That is what I mean.
That sounds frightening....has this been happening to you?
I screwed up...I really can't ask her to her face right now, can I?
*ALARM*
Useless! Nutzlos! Nutzlos!
Huh? What's wrong with the virtues? Thought they were orderly listed out. Was it in the wrong order or something?
Nein! The virtues...are all...useless!
Roeder, that is exactly the opposite of what you should be saying right now.
It is not! All my life I was brainwashed to follow the Prussian virtues. Who is to say it enhances a life? It makes it more miserable.
That is not true. You were the happiest when talking about your Prussian virtues. You can't throw all of that away!
I have and I will...

Fields.MenuText: You will regret it, Roeder.
Do you really want to throw away something people lovingly taught you about?
Restraint... Please, show it right now. Courage, bravery. The strongest of the virtues.

Fields.DialogueText: Nein, I will not. I will never regret something that had me shackled.
Ja...It is better to be free of those silly virtues than to be bound by falsehoods.
They are not real virtues. Stop acting like they are!
I am keeping all these virtues. You may tear them down, but they are important to you. On some level, I know they will reach you again.
Tsk, fine, keep garbage for all I care. Because, that is what you are, after all.
*ALARM*
I'll be doing with the Morganas if you need me...
@BATTLE
Bravery, courage, self-denial, probity, determination...
What are you rambling about, sailor?
Ah, dear Roeder. I do not know what man or woman you seek in a person, but I have decided.
I refuse.
But I didn't say anything.
I know what you will ask. Satisfied?
Wow, that sounded really harsh to that Thorsten guy. I've never seen him so sad before.
On the contrary, I do not feel an ounce of guilt for that man.
Why not? Wouldn't you feel bad if someone you love rejects you?
No, I have prevented that man from inheriting any pain that I might have harbored within me, Kapitän.

Fields.MenuText: Did you love Thorsten though?
I still don't know what your illness is...
I doubt your illness is that contagious, Roeder.

Fields.DialogueText: Nein. Hard to love someone who gave ill advice to you.
All you have to know is that it makes me suffer.
You do not understand how this illness transforms and mutates, Kapitän.
Anyway, I will be preparing for the Nixe which will arrive shortly. Will I see you there, Kapitän?
Of course.
@BATTLE
I have learned about all of the Prussian virtues. I am able to protect you with everything I have, and–
*ALARM*
Today, we dine! Dine not on food, but the wine of our enemies!
I think it's blood–
Halt's Maul! I am attempting to be clever!
@BATTLE
Ah...If nothing in life can cure me, then Limburger can take some of the pain off at least.
Roeder, have you seen the plan- dear heavens, what is that smell!?
Oh welcome back, Kapitän, I have acquired a delightful cheese that I would love to share with you.
Limburger is one of the finest stinky cheeses in Germany. I want to discover if there is a better way to consume this cheese.
Normally, I have it by itself, but this time... I will try it on bread!

Fields.MenuText: Uh...let me know how it tastes.
Well, at least this time I know better than to throw it off the ship.
Can I have a taste?

Fields.DialogueText: Nein, you will taste it with me if you have any hopes of knowing what my illness is. A big bite!
Of course, discipline and sense of order helped you this time. Please, take a bite of this cheese.
Hm...You have done well to not run away so far. I will permit it.
On drei. Eins, zwei, drei! Om!
I now no longer doubt you have the embodiment of sincerity. Never again will I doubt!
W-w-ate...
A waiter? We have none aboard this ship, but we shall try to make Thorsten into one!
H-h-elp.... the smell.... light....
*ALARM*
*nom*
Hm, that is delightful, Kapitän! What did you-ah... You are overcome with joy! I can see it in your face!
Ready for battle! Make sure that Roeder... Roeder?
@BATTLE
Roeder?...What are you doing? Why are you in the fetal position?
Nein...Please...do not see me like this.
Well, I already do, now I'm asking what is wrong. Look, you've been keeping this illness to yourself long enough. It's time to tell me.
Do I have to?
Yes! And I'm not having you disappear on me again until I hear at least a little bit of what it's about.
Have you ever heard of illnesses that affect the brain, Kapitän?
Hm... like mental disorders?
Yes... I have one of those. That is all I can utter about this subject.
Honestly?
I am not lying to you! I don't have the heart to talk about it at this moment in time.

Fields.MenuText: So that's why you've been acting strange...
Was what the doctor said really that detrimental to your well being, that it has effected your work?
Is there anything I can do to help you, Roeder?

Fields.DialogueText: You really have no idea what it is like to have one of these disorders, do you?
... Nothing.
Roeder, wait!
... Well, I know what's going on. Sort of. A step in the right direction, I suppose.
That girl has something, I need to... Dammit, not now! Morganas in sight!
@BATTLE
Huh? The cargo bay door is open this time. Roeder?
*sniff...uwaa* Kapitän? Is that you?
Roeder?! Are you all right? What have you done?! It's like a bomb's gone off in here...
I am sorry, Kapitän... I could not hold it anymore... The act of being stronger than I really was. How much longer could I let the rest of Schiffsdamen believe I could really regain my title?
Weak... that is all I am... Prussian virtues did not help me, neither did this illness.
Roeder, it's okay. I'm here. But you have to talk to me now, okay? Please help me understand.
Do you promise not to judge me and change your outlook of who I am, Kapitän?
I promise.
The doctor called it "melancholia," or depression. Do you know what they do to people who have such an illness? Do you know what they would do to a ship made useless by her broken mind?
You're not listening! There are no sanitariums for someone like me. There are no medicines. I would be a burden, and this is not a war for burdens.
I have to be fine. I have to be fine to the other Schiffsdamen. No matter how hard it is, I have to appear all right.

Fields.MenuText: You don't have to appear "fine" alone. I'm with you.
Why did you hide this from me?
Ssh. Just breathe.

Fields.DialogueText: Kapitän... I am sorry. You are the only one who I confide my feelings to... I am so sorry...
I do not know who will sympathize with me in the end. If the one person whom I trust the most does not care about me, what is the point of continuing on?
I'm just...
Sshh... We'll get through this together. Just rest for now, Roeder.
Danke...
Hey. You're not useless.
Roeder, how are you feeling?
A little better than before, Kapitän.
Can we talk?
Ja.
What caused you to start feeling like this? The last I remember, we confronted the guilt you had about Engelke. What happened?
... No matter how strong I really am, my family... I miss them.
But I do not deserve to go back.
When I realized this, the physical feelings, headaches, spasms throughout my body, aches... were obvious at first...
Then came the sense of worthlessness.
Remember the on-call doctor? He was going to try and have me locked up in a cell to watch my emotions.
I know I am a Schiffsdame and can manifest where I please, but the fact he wanted to imprison me, much less observe me, made me feel horrified.
I could not imagine if I was not a Schiffsdame...

Fields.MenuText: Roeder, I'm sure he was only trying to help you...

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps, but I did not stay to find out. I poked around some of his medical records when he was asleep. Sometimes they did horrible things to the patients that were hospitalized.
Whether I was institutionalized or not, I still had these feelings within me that I could not get rid of and probably have to live with for the rest of my life.
I have found that... not many people actually treat this illness - less so now than a decade or so ago - and there's no guarantee of relief.
I am fearful that I will live with plague for the rest of my life and one day, it will claim me in a bloody battle.
Listen, for what it's worth - your sisters, wherever they are, don't want you to constantly worry and miss them all the time. If that's part of what's weighing you down...
How can you say that?
Would your sisters want you to be alone facing this illness by yourself?
Nein...
Would they want you to get better?
Ja...
Then let's work on that for them. Stick near me, Roeder. I may not be able to cure you, but I can at least be there when living becomes too painful.
I will be there to help with your bloody wounds and your outbursts. But, for heaven's sake, you have got to talk to me. Don't face this by yourself. As your Kapitän, that's an order.
... Ja, danke, Kapitän. Danke for not abandoning me.

Fields.MenuText: Just don't lock the doors again. I can't manifest into rooms like you.
Roeder, I will always be here. I'm not going anywhere.
Always trust me, Roeder. Even if it's hard. Always do so.

Fields.DialogueText: Heh. I will remember that in the future.
You promise. And I will believe so. Danke, Kapitän.
I do trust you, Kapitän. It's myself I have problems with.
Huh... on cue, huh? Let's show those Nixen who's in command, huh?
After you, Kapitän!
*ALARM*
Does there have to be a cause? You said it was like a bomb went off in the cargo hold. That's just what bombs do.
Hey. I won't have you insulting my good friend like that.
But there, too, I will try.

Fields.MenuText: I hadn't realized it was that bad.

Fields.DialogueText: I... poked around some of his medical records when he was asleep. Sometimes they did horrible things to the patients that were hospitalized.

Fields.MenuText: I wouldn't have let it happen. You know that, right?

Fields.DialogueText: Would you have had a choice?
Oh, I think so. I'm not an easy person to keep quiet.
... I poked around some of his medical records when the doctor was asleep. Sometimes they did horrible things to the patients that were hospitalized Kapitän.
Trust me, Roeder. You're no bomb.
Perhaps my sisters would miss me. Though God knows I'm of no use to them now.
